word.entryDescription: (=bike) a vehicle with two wheels which is powered by the rider's own legs
word.entryExample: Bicycles are available to hire in my town.

word.entryDescription: large in size
word.entryExample: Their grandma lives in a big house.

word.entryDescription: (=bicycle) a vehicle with two wheels which you turn by pushing with your feet and legs
word.entryExample: Jill rides her bike in the park.

word.entryDescription: a place where bikes are serviced or repaired
word.entryExample: There's a bike repair shop in the high street.

word.entryDescription: a written statement showing how much money you need to pay
word.entryExample: I'd like to pay my bill by card.

word.entryDescription: a large board for advertisements in an outside public place
word.entryExample: The company will spend a great deal of money for the ads on billboards in the entire country.

word.entryDescription: a container used for putting rubbish in
word.entryExample: Put your paper in the bin.

word.entryDescription: (past form 'bound') to tie or wrap something/somebody
word.entryExample: The kidnappers bound his hands.

word.entryDescription: the variety of plant and animal life
word.entryExample: Biodiversity projects can help to protect endangered species.

word.entryDescription: telling the story of or connected with a person's life
word.entryExample: I'm really interested in other people's lives – I love biographical films.

word.entryDescription: the story of somebody's life, written by another person
word.entryExample: I've just read a really interesting biography about the life of my favourite actor.

word.entryDescription: a scientist studying biology
word.entryExample: Rainforests give zoologists, botanists and biologists the opportunity to do research.

word.entryDescription: the study of living things
word.entryExample: I didn't do very well in my biology exam.

word.entryDescription: a type of major ecological community with characteristic plants and animals that exist there (e.g. rainforest, or desert biome)
word.entryExample: The temperature in the Mediterranean biome changes within a maximum of 25 and a minimum of 9 degrees centigrade.

word.entryDescription: an animal with feathers and wings that lays eggs and can usually fly
word.entryExample: There's a bird in the tree.

word.entryDescription: the anniversary of your birth
word.entryExample: How do you celebrate your birthday?

word.entryDescription: a card with a picture you give somebody on their birthday
word.entryExample: My aunt sent me a funny birthday card.

word.entryDescription: a small, hard cake often eaten as a snack
word.entryExample: Would you like a biscuit with your tea?

word.entryDescription: having a strong sharp taste like raw coffee
word.entryExample: A lot of children don't like the bitter taste of some green vegetables, like broccoli.

word.entryDescription: something that is black is the colour of the night sky
word.entryExample: His hair is black.

word.entryDescription: a bruise around the eye
word.entryExample: It's just a black eye and a bloody nose. He'll be fine.

word.entryDescription: to say or think that someone or something is responsible for something bad
word.entryExample: The victim blamed the pickpocket for stealing her wallet.

word.entryDescription: with little flavour
word.entryExample: I didn't like the food very much. It was really bland.

word.entryDescription: a cloth cover used on a bed to keep you warm
word.entryExample: We're going camping, bring a warm blanket with you.

word.entryDescription: to lose blood, often through an injury
word.entryExample: I've hurt my leg and my knee is bleeding!

word.entryDescription: unable to see
word.entryExample: My grandmother is completely blind.

word.entryDescription: bright and making it difficult to see
word.entryExample: Suddenly, there was a blinding flash of light and a huge bang.

word.entryDescription: a small raised area of skin containing liquid often caused by rubbing or burning
word.entryExample: I took off my boots and was horrified to see swellings on both my ankles, and my feet were covered in blisters.

word.entryDescription: a severe snowstorm with a strong wind
word.entryExample: The blizzard struck in the evening.

word.entryDescription: a big building containing lots of apartments
word.entryExample: The block of flats looks freshly painted and modern.

word.entryDescription: a person who makes marks or holes in a piece of wood or stone
word.entryExample: Block-cutters were specialist craftsmen who dealt with block-carving.

word.entryDescription: a thing that blocks movement through some narrow place
word.entryExample: Food waste put into a sink can cause a blockage in a pipe.

word.entryDescription: a website where someone writes regularly about their opinions, experiences or topics that interest them
word.entryExample: Well, he’s gone from not knowing how to switch a computer onto writing up a weekly blog about his garden.

word.entryDescription: blonde hair is pale yellow or gold
word.entryExample: She's tall and thin, and her hair is long and blonde.

word.entryDescription: the red liquid which flows around inside your body
word.entryExample: I hate scary films with lots of blood and shocking plots.

word.entryDescription: the force with which blood moves through the body
word.entryExample: I need to have my blood pressure taken.

word.entryDescription: putting new blood into someone's body as a medical treatment
word.entryExample: The British Red Cross set up a national blood transfusion service.

word.entryDescription: to make air flow
word.entryExample: It was blowing a terrible gale at the time.

word.entryDescription: something that is blue is the colour of the sky
word.entryExample: I've got blue eyes.

word.entryDescription: a small mostly blue bird living in North America
word.entryExample: The bluebird is a very helpful garden bird. Since it eats lots of insects it helps the gardeners in getting rid of insect pests.

word.entryDescription: a wide flat object often fixed to a wall which a teacher writes on with chalk or a large pen
word.entryExample: Please write your name on the board.

word.entryDescription: a pass you show before getting on a plane or boat
word.entryExample: You have to check in and get your boarding card before you get on the plane.

word.entryDescription: a small vehicle we use for travelling on water
word.entryExample: We can sail this boat on the lake.

word.entryDescription: to cook in boiling water
word.entryExample: I burnt my hand on the saucepan when I was boiling an egg for breakfast.

word.entryDescription: to order a room in advance
word.entryExample: Good evening, could I book a room for tonight?

word.entryDescription: a piece of furniture with shelves that you keep books in
word.entryExample: We should buy a new bookcase.

word.entryDescription: a reservation, an arrangement made in advance to buy a ticket, go to theatre, restaurant, etc
word.entryExample: She phoned and changed our ferry booking.

word.entryDescription: a shelf on which you keep books
word.entryExample: I've got my school stuff on my bookshelves.

word.entryDescription: shoe that covers the foot and the lower part of the leg
word.entryExample: When my new boots didn't fit, I took them back to the shop and exchanged them.

word.entryDescription: feeling tired or unhappy because something is not interesting
word.entryExample: Were you bored by that trip to the castle?
